supporting_quotes: Emília Pires was East Timor's Minister of Finance from April 2007 until 16 February 2015.
In office 7 April 2007 – 16 February 2015
Ms. Pires was sworn in as the Minister of Finance of the V Constitutional Government of East Timor on August 8, 2012 under the leadership of Prime Minister Xanana Gusmão.

roles: panel member advising on Post-2015 Development Agenda
supporting_quotes: In July 2012, Pires was appointed by the Secretary-General of United Nations, Ban Ki-moon, to the 26-member High-level Panel of Eminent Persons advising the United Nations on the post 2015 global development agenda.
Pires began her professional career as a junior public servant in the Victorian Government in her early 20s. She then rose to senior management level.

roles: Senior Aid Management Specialist in West Bank and Gaza
supporting_quotes: World Bank, Senior Aid Management Specialist in West Bank and Gaza, where she advised both the Ministries of Finance and Planning of the Palestinian Authority and donors on aid coordination to the economic sector

roles: Senior Advisor to the East Timor Ministry of Planning and Finance
supporting_quotes: United Nations, UNMISET's Senior Advisor to the East Timor Ministry of Planning and Finance

roles: Head of the Planning Commission Secretariat
supporting_quotes: UNTAET's Head of the Planning Commission Secretariat as well as the Chief of the National Development and Planning Agency (NPDA)
UNTAET's Head of the Planning Commission Secretariat as well as the Chief of the National Development and Planning Agency (NPDA)
Chief of the National Development and Planning Agency (NPDA).
Emilia Pires was selected to be the first Chair of the g7+, the first forum of its kind giving fragile and conflict-affected countries a voice and place to share issues and ideas.
Pires held the role until May 2014, when Minister Kaifala Marah of Sierra Leone took over.

organizations: International Dialogue of Peacebuilding and Statebuilding
supporting_quotes: Until June 2014, Pires co-chaired the International Dialogue of Peacebuilding and Statebuilding with Denmark and later with Finland

roles: chair of Working Group to produce first East Timor National Human Development Report
supporting_quotes: Emilia Pires led the planning process for the first Timorese National Development Plan and East Timor's Vision 2020, as well as chairing the UNDP Working Group to produce the first East Timor National Human Development Report.
a bachelor's degree majoring in Mathematics (Statistics) from La Trobe University
post graduate studies in Government Law from the University of Melbourne

organizations: London School of Economics and Political Science
roles: Masters of Science graduate in Development Management
supporting_quotes: a Masters of Science in Development Management from the London School of Economics and Political Science in the UK.

Co-authored 'How will the Macroeconomy be Managed in an Independent East Timor? An East Timorese view' with East Timor President of the Republic, H,E. Jose Ramos-Horta in 2001, published in the IMF's Finance and Development Magazine.

organizations: Peace and the Public Purse: Economic Policies for Postwar Statebuilding
supporting_quotes: Co-authored 'National Ownership and International Trusteeship: the Case of Timor-Leste', with Mr. Michael Francino in 2007, published in Boyce James K. and Madalene O'Donnell (eds) in the Peace and the Public Purse: Economic Policies for Postwar Statebuilding.

organizations: Senior Level Forum on Development Effectiveness in Fragile States
supporting_quotes: the Senior Level Forum on Development Effectiveness in Fragile States in London organized by DFID, OECD, World Bank, UNDP and European Union
the 'Deepening Voice and Accountability to fight poverty' Dialogue sponsored by the Communication Implementers in Paris

roles: co-chair of session on 'New Development Challenges and New Development Partnerships'
supporting_quotes: the 3rd High-Level Forum on Aid Effectiveness held in Accra, Ghana where she co-chaired the session on 'New Development Challenges and New Development Partnerships: the Relevance and Urgency of Aid Reform'
